title: Lesson 10: Osmosis and Water Potential
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding osmosis, water potential, and tonicity. Students learn to calculate water potential and predict cell behaviour in different solutions.
learningIntentions: Students can define osmosis as the diffusion of water across a selectively permeable membrane.
Students can calculate water potential using ψ = ψs + ψp and predict water movement direction.
Students can predict and explain cell behaviour (lysis, crenation, turgidity, plasmolysis) in different tonicities.

engagementHook.title: To Burst or Not to Burst
engagementHook.content: Show images: a wilted plant after watering (recovers), a red blood cell in pure water (bursts). 'Both cells are in pure water. One thrives, one dies. The difference lies in water potential and one critical structure that animal cells lack. Today we solve the mystery of osmotic survival.'

keyConcepts.definition: The net movement of water molecules from an area of high water potential (low solute concentration) to an area of low water potential (high solute concentration) across a selectively permeable membrane.

Measure of the potential energy of water, measured in MPa (megapascals) or kPa. Determines direction of water movement. Higher ψ (less negative) to lower ψ (more negative). Pure water at atmospheric pressure = 0 MPa (reference point).
Effect of dissolved solutes on water potential. Always negative or zero (solutes reduce water potential). More solute = more negative ψs.
Physical pressure on water. Can be positive (turgor pressure in plants) or zero (open beaker). Increases water potential.
Relative solute concentration of a solution compared to a cell. Isotonic = same concentration. Hypotonic = lower solute (higher water potential). Hypertonic = higher solute (lower water potential).

misconceptions.misconception: Water moves toward high solute concentration
misconceptions.correction: Water moves toward LOW water potential (which happens to be where solute concentration is high). Focus on water potential, not solute chasing.
Plants face plasmolysis in hypertonic solutions (salt water, drought) - membrane pulls away from wall.

misconceptions.misconception: Pure water has negative water potential
misconceptions.correction: Pure water at atmospheric pressure is the reference: ψ = 0. Adding solutes makes it negative.

contentSections.title: Water Potential
contentSections.content: Diagram showing ψ = ψs + ψp equation. Solute potential always negative. Pressure potential positive in turgid plant cells. Water moves from high ψ to low ψ.
keyPoints: ψs is always ≤ 0 (zero for pure water)
ψp is ≥ 0 (positive for pressure, zero for open system)
Water moves toward more negative ψ
contentSections.example: Pure water: ψs = 0, ψp = 0, ψ = 0. Cell with solutes: ψs = -0.5, ψp = 0.3, ψ = -0.2.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Which way will water move: from ψ = -0.2 MPa to ψ = -0.8 MPa, or the reverse? (From -0.2 to -0.8 - toward lower potential)

contentSections.title: Water Potential Calculations
contentSections.content: Example 1: ψs = -0.8 MPa, ψp = 0.4 MPa. ψ = -0.8 + 0.4 = -0.4 MPa. Example 2: Pure water ψ = 0. Flaccid plant cell in pure water: water enters (ψ cell < 0), cell swells, ψp increases until ψ cell = 0 (equilibrium with surroundings). At this point, cell is turgid.
contentSections.example: Marine algae in seawater (ψ ≈ -2.5 MPa) vs freshwater algae (ψ cell ≈ -0.3 MPa).

multipleChoice.question: A plant cell is placed in a solution with water potential of -0.2 MPa. The cell's water potential is -0.4 MPa. What will happen?
options: Water will enter the cell and it will become turgid
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Water will enter the cell and it will become turgid
multipleChoice.rationale: Water moves from high ψ (-0.2) to low ψ (-0.4). Cell gains water, becomes turgid. Cell wall prevents bursting.

multipleChoice.question: What is the water potential of pure water at atmospheric pressure?
multipleChoice.rationale: Pure water at atmospheric pressure is the reference point (0 MPa). Adding solutes makes it negative.

multipleChoice.question: Why do animal cells burst in pure water but plant cells become turgid?
options: Animal cells have higher water potential
Plant cells have a cell wall that resists expansion
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Plant cells have a cell wall that resists expansion
multipleChoice.rationale: Both cells take in water in hypotonic solutions. Plant cell walls provide turgor pressure; animal cells lack walls and burst (lysis).

definitions: Osmosis: Net movement of water from high water potential to low water potential across a selectively permeable membrane.
Water potential (ψ) = ψs (solute potential) + ψp (pressure potential).
Pure water ψ = 0 MPa (reference point). Adding solutes makes ψ negative.
Water moves from less negative (higher) ψ to more negative (lower) ψ.
Hypotonic: cell gains water; Hypertonic: cell loses water; Isotonic: no net change.
keyPoints: ψp is ≥ 0 (positive for pressure, zero for open)
Animal cells: lyse in hypotonic, crenate in hypertonic
Plant cells: turgid in hypotonic, flaccid in isotonic, plasmolysis in hypertonic
Cell wall prevents plant cells from bursting
diagrams: Water potential equation with labelled components

shortAnswer: Water potential (ψ) = solute potential (ψs) + pressure potential (ψp) ψ = -0.6 MPa + 0.2 MPa = -0.4 MPa

Both animal and plant cells will take in water when placed in pure water because pure water has a higher water potential (0 MPa or 0 kPa) than the cell contents, which contain solutes. However, animal cells lack a cell wall, so as water enters, the cell swells and continues to expand until the cell membrane ruptures (lysis or cytolysis). Plant cells, on the other hand, have a rigid cell wall outside the cell membrane. As water enters the plant cell, the vacuole expands and presses the cytoplasm against the cell wall. The cell wall resists this expansion and creates turgor pressure, which makes the cell firm and turgid. The cell wall prevents the plant cell from bursting, so it becomes turgid instead.
